ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Oh yes, Being and Time is one of those texts everyone should have some familiarity with, and after this class you will be a more critical reader of Heideggerian-inflected theoretical writing.

Absolutely! You will be in good hands with HÃ¤gglund. He will always make time to meet with you, and talk to you about your ideas. He is very kind and attentive. Not to mention the opportunity to read Being and Time.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I am a Romanticist, not a student of philosophy. But so much theory and criticism has been influenced by Heidegger and other phenomenological writings (for good reason: they have things in common). Now I can participate better in that discussion and be a more critical reader of the goings on in the discipline.
Contributed very much to my research.

It is a notoriously difficult book to read, and the chance to read it in such detail and to grapple with it is very rare. The course offered an experience of a book that all comparative literature students should know.
